instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.SMC_BATLOW_L: What is SMC_BATLOW_L? SMC_BATLOW_L refers to a power management signal that indicates a low battery condition. The "_L" suffix suggests that this is an active-low signal, meaning that it becomes low when the battery reaches a low voltage threshold..

threads.title: 820 2936 dead
threads.message:
Any pulse at least at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>?
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check again.
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>?
Also check <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: 820 2936 dead
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 3.45v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.32v
3v3 SUS 0v
No pulse on <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, at least none that my multi meter could pick up. Toggled SMC ON/OFF, no change.

threads.title: 820 2936 dead
threads.message: Yes, 0v PM BATLOW L measurement taken from pin 2 @ <TRANSISTOR>Q5040</TRANSISTOR>. I am using an OEM Apple 85w Magsafe 1

threads.title: 820 2936 dead
threads.message:
PCH will not start power on sequence untill <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> goes high.
Any history available?
You may need to replace SMC, or reflow it at least.
Check <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> signal, as <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> too.

threads.title: 820 2936 dead
threads.message:
No real history machine just stopped powering on as far as I know. The board looks like its in good shap, no LD.

<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.470v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> 3.201v

threads.message:
Check if all 4 RTC signals have high level (page 16).
32KHz output from <CHIP>U2800</CHIP> should be present too.

threads.title: 820 2936 dead
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>.
If high, then should be PCH issue, pulling down <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>.
In such case use good flux and heat PCH.
You may have luck and is only some crap under...

threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> is 0v

threads.title: 820 2936 dead
threads.message:
If you are sure about original Apple 60/85W charger, then could be SMC issue.
You can try to reflow it; change it if no result...

threads.title: 820 2936 dead
threads.message: Im positive this is a 100% working OEM Apple charger, I bought it straight from the Apple store. I replaced the SMC, no change.

threads.title: 820 2936 dead
threads.message:
Try to start in SMC bypass mode, just in case.
Also try to start with battery and charger, both connected?
Not normal, but is possible that PCH blocks the SMC and this keeps <SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> low.

Can you confirm with o-scope 32KHz square wave output from <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>?
Frequency meter is also good enough.

threads.title: 820 2936 dead
threads.message: Tried SMC Bypass, and batt/charger, no change. Unfortunately I do not have a scope or a frequency meter.
